xqpmv2wX2KwjdnIiT9_A9w.text: Had lunch here the other day with a couple of friends.  We all had a bento set each. My salmon teriyaki set was filling, tasty, with good variety. I almost couldn't finish it. The sashimi was fresh, the chawan mushi silky and delicious. Good value for money

4DNsuB4ASoNwK8pE4hgHOA.text: I thought I would find Botan Shrimp on the menu but I didn't. Hah...but this Japanese restaurant serves up pretty delicious dishes that taste very close to those you find in Japanese homes. On the dinner menu, you'll find a list of Dinner Sets, ala carte sashimi, Yakitori, porridge, soba, sushi, tofu, tempura, etc.  The Gyunikyu Jagaimo is a flavourful simple beef stew with the caramelized sweetness of onions and carrots. Soft, creamy yet not spammed with too much mayonnaise. The Tamago yaki takes semblance after dashi-maki, served warm and significantly less sweeter. I felt short-changed on the Stir-fry Beef with Leeks as the greens were in shortage and the dish was too oily. And I'm sure most Japanese housewives would raise opposition towards this. Though being cruelly severed into slices, the Unagi Kabayaki ($15) remained a crowd pleaser with its fatty tissues that gave a full, tantalizing mouthfeel. If you love potato salad, then you should try the version here at $8 as it is probably the best I've come accords in Singapore. Not to forget the light low-calorie supper food Tofu Mentaiko; anything hardly goes wrong if you throw in some mentaiko and this is no exception :)

photos.caption: Photo of Botan Japanese Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Botan Japanese Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Botan Japanese Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

aYdG_lYvH8l6xuAoDZo63A.text: I read about this place from an online food review site, and decided to try this place for myself since I am such a fan of Japanese food.First of all, I had some difficulty trying to locate this place; to be honest, it was hidden in a small and hard to locate area, and it took me quite a while to find it.The décor of this place was very pleasant and the service was impeccable.I ordered the pork tonkatsu set, and the first thing that I noticed is that the serving is HUGE! The set came with the pork itself, a bowl of rice, chawanmushi, a medium slice of grilled chicken and some watermelon. The pork was nice although I have had more flavorful one. But this one is definitely way above average.Overall, I am definitely very satisfied with the quality of the food and the service here, and would definitely return here again for some awesome Japanese food!

photos.caption: Photo of Botan Japanese Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

Ul7xUqH5uPDi2FqBRNT9Tw.text: My first visit here today and I was impressed.  The place is hard to find as the entrance/name is covered by the neighbouring restaurant's awning.  I walked by twice before I found the place. It was worth the search.I had the tempura sashimi lunch box. Every thing was fresh and tasty and the tempura was crisp.  The portions were generous and staff was friendly. I'll be back.

_tYH3kR2DVVp8ARunvoq7w.text: We used to come here for celebratory team lunches. I still haven't figured out why the ladies' bento sets were larger than most other sets. But hey, something for everyone at lunch time. A la carte is definitely the way to go at dinner though--I really like the housemade tofu, and the clear soup with grilled mochi. There are also various deep-fried, stir-fried, soup-based whatevers to tickle your fancy, but what you really should do is to smile at the lady-boss (who is married to the Japanese chef) what's in season. Or to translate the lines in the menu that have no English equivalent, because that's how you hear of the existence of whale bacon and horse sashimi...or you could just eat yakisoba like the Japanese businessmen do...

nSOJ_P6ckUuzHyr7Pslv5A.text: Botan's one of my favourite Japanese places in the Shenton Way area for lunch. Good quality Japanese food and efficient service, very commendable. Sometimes the troops trundle over after a round of drinks after work for dinner.Food: Well, the bento boxes are good value and the sashimi's pretty decent. As are the tempura and sushi etc.Ambience: Quite a noisy lunch crowd, go early to avoid waiting.Service: Prompt and efficient.

FgRGItM66BH7-ETX1HqO5A.text: Decent by Singapore standards but nothing to rave about. The breading on the tempura was too hard and the sushi, though fresh, was cut in super small slices. I also ordered the umeshu with rocks ($9) and was disappointed to see that the waitress only filled up 1/3 of the glass when served.

pGCB1TUCwtSi4uX6QgWkOg.text: The bento sets here are great value for money in general but when I come here I always get the kaisen-don. $20 for a huge bowl of fresh raw fish + roe is a steal. Also a big fan of the umaki tamago (unagi in egg roll).It's crowded during lunchtime because of the Raffles Place crowd, but quiet during dinner.
